title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit access spread globally, leading the Federal Reserve to establish a target range of 0% to 0.25% in response to the crisis. The Board of Governors acknowledged the severity of the situation and acted under "unusual and exigent circumstances". The Federal Reserve has exercised its authority to address "unusual and exigent circumstances" multiple times since the financial crisis began in 2007, extending assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959. The Federal Reserve extended assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959 and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981. Additionally, joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets during the crisis, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed transparency commitment in 2009. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank, including onsite examinations when deemed necessary. This includes reviewing the establishment of credit facilities for actions approved by the Board under the Federal Reserve Act or providing temporary assistance to private institutions as the lender of last resort. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 allows the Board to provide temporary assistance to private institutions as the lender of last resort through various credit facilities, including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, and Term Securities Lending Facility. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes the Board to provide temporary assistance through various credit facilities, including the Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane LLC, Maiden Lane II LLC, Maiden Lane III LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles. This authority expires after a 5-year period from enactment. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes temporary assistance through various credit facilities and special purpose vehicles. The authority expires after a 5-year period, and a report on each review conducted must be submitted to Congress by the Comptroller General. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. The Comptroller General shall have access to the officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility established by an agency to request and retain copies of records. Unauthorized access to records includes copies of any records from agencies or credit facilities.
